body: Hi, can you assign this to me, please?

Very good suggestions. Thank you, @scordio.

`isNumeric()` implies _this is a string representation of a number — ANY number_
`containsOnlyDigits()` says _this string contains ONLY digits_

The names `containsOnlyDigits()` and `isDigit()` are consistent with the POSIX character class `\p{Digit} — A decimal digit: [0-9]`. The character class is _not_ named `\p{Numeric}`. Naming consistency is useful to both API maintainers and consumers.

Assertions should be named to adhere to the _Principle of Least Surprise_ — they should behave as most API consumers would expect them to. E.g., the presence of a distinct `isHexadecimal()` assertion informs me that `\p{Digit}` will not match all valid numeric string representations, hexadecimal strings among them.

I would expect an `isNumeric()` assertion to succeed with the `float` string `"12.03456789"`

```java
String floatStr = "12.03456789";
assertThat(floatStr).isNumeric();
```

Given that the example `float` (and many other valid numeric String representations) do not match `\p{Digit}`, it would be clearer to indicate that the assertion succeeds _only_ if the string contains solely digits, i.e., `isDigit()`.

issue.title: `containsOnlyDigits()` was deprecated without alternative in `3.24.1`

labels.name: theme: documentation
labels.description: An issue related to the documentation

repository.name: assertj
repository.description: Fluent testing assertions for Java and the JVM

issue.body:
Not a bug, but a question. The string assertion `containsOnlyDigits()` has been marked as deprecated in commit 88e252e5a9. There doesn't seem to be an alternative method and no mention of this in the release notes.

Was this an intentional change? If so, what method should be used instead?

* assertj core version: `3.24.1`
